title-group.article-title: Undescribed phloroglucinol derivatives with antiviral activities from Dryopteris atrata (Wall. Ex Kunze) Ching

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Undescribed phloroglucinol derivatives with antiviral activities from
Dryopteris atrata (Wall. Ex Kunze) Ching

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Phloroglucinol derivatives
Structural elucidation
Antiviral activities
A B S T R A C T

Nine undescribed phloroglucinol derivatives (dryatraols A-I) with five different backbones and three known dimeric acylphloroglucinols were isolated from the rhizome of
Dryopteris atrata (Wall. Ex Kunze) Ching (Dryopteridaceae)
. Dryatraol A contains an unprecedented carbon skeleton—a butyrylphloroglucinol and a rulepidanol-type sesquiterpene are linked via a furan ring to form a 6/5/6/6 ring system. Dryatraols B and C are the first examples of monomeric phloroglucinols coupled with the aristolane-type sesquiterpene through the C–C bond. Dryatraol D features a rare spiro [benzofuran-2 ′ ,5 ′′ -furan] backbone. Dryatraols E-I are five undescribed adducts with a butyrylphloroglucinol or filicinic acid incorporated into the germacrene-type sesquiterpene via a pyran ring. These undescribed structures were determined by comprehensively analysing the spectroscopic data, X-ray diffraction results, and electronic circular dichroism calculations. The result of in vitro antiviral activity evaluation indicated that dryatraol C displayed the strongest antiviral effect against both respiratory syncytial virus and influenza A virus (H1N1), with IC 50 values of 11.9 μM and 5.5 μM, respectively. Dryatraols F–H exhibited considerable inhibitory activity against herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1), with IC 50 values ranging from 2.6 to 6.3 μM. Analysis of the inhibitory mechanism using a time-of-addition assay revealed that dryatraol G may inhibit the replication of HSV-1 by interfering with the late stage of the viral life cycle.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: * Corresponding author. The First Affiliated Hospital, Jinan University, 613 Huangpu Avenue West, Guangzhou, 510630, China .

** Corresponding author. Guangdong Clinical Translational Center for Targeted Drug, Department of Pharmacology, School of Medicine, Jinan University, 601 Huangpu Avenue West, Guangzhou, 510630, China .

*** Corresponding author. Institute of Traditional Chinese Medicine & Natural Products, Guangdong Province Key Laboratory of Pharmacodynamic Constituents of TCM and New Drugs Research, College of Pharmacy, Jinan University, 601 Huangpu Avenue West, Guangzhou, 510630, China .
E-mail addresses: twangguocai@jnu.edu.cn (G.-c. Wang), ybzhang99@126.com (Y.-b. Zhang), chennengflo@163.com (N.-h. Chen).
1 The authors contributed equally to this work.

The phytochemical composition of the rhizome of
D. atrata
was studied as a part of our ongoing research on
Dryopteris
plants. Nine undescribed phloroglucinol derivatives ( 1–9 ) and three known dimeric acylphloroglucinols ( 10–12 ) were isolated. The structures of the compounds were determined by interpretation of spectroscopic data, X-ray diffraction, and electronic circular dichroism calculations. Most isolates were evaluated for antiviral activity against respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), influenza A virus (H1N1), and herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1). Herein, we report a detailed isolation, structural elucidation, and evaluation of antiviral activity of these compounds.

sec.title: 2.1. Structural elucidation
sec.p: The relative configuration was determined by coupling constants and interpretation of the NOESY data. The correlations of H-6’ ( δ H 2.31) and H 3 -14’ ( δ H 1.10)/H 3 -15’ ( δ H 0.99)indicated that these protons were located on the same side and arbitrarily designated as α -orientation. The correlations of H-2’ ( δ H 3.18) and H-4’ ( δ H 2.59), H-1’ ( δ H 5.00)/H-4’ ( δ H 2.59) and H 3 -13’ ( δ H 1.22) suggested that H-1 ′ , H-2 ′ , and H-4 ′ were cofacial and β -oriented. The Z -geometry of the C-7/C-8 olefin is consistent with the observed coupling constant ( J 7 8 = 9.7 Hz). To determine the absolute configuration of 1 , the quantum chemical calculations on (1 ′ S , 2 ′ R , 4 ′ R , 5 ′ R , 6 ′ R )- 1 and (1 ′ R , 2 ′ S , 4 ′ S , 5 ′ S , 6 ′ S )- 1 were calculated, as well as a comparison between the calculated and the experimental ECD spectra was performed. The calculated ECD spectrum for (1 ′ R , 2 ′ S , 4 ′ S , 5 ′ S , 6 ′ S )- 1 was in agreement with the experimental one. Accordingly, the structure of dryatraol A was established.
Overlapped signals are reported without designating multiplicity.
a Measured in CDCl.
3 b Measured in MeOD.

Dryatraol B ( 2 ) had a molecular formula of C 23 H 30 O 4 as established by its 13 C NMR and HRESIMS data ( m/z 371.2214 [M + H] + , calculated for C 23 H 31 O 4 , 371.2217). The 1D NMR data of 2 (Figures S22 and S23, Supplementary data) presented two sets of signals in a ratio of approximately 5:2 ( 2a : 2b ). The 1 H NMR spectrum of the major isomer 2a showed signals assigned to five methyl groups [ δ H 2.68, 1.21, 1.19, 1.08 (each 3H, s), and 0.99 (3H, d, J = 6.9 Hz)], an olefinic methine [ δ H 5.29 (1H, d, J = 4.1 Hz)], an aromatic proton [ δ H 5.79 (1H, s)], and two phenolic hydroxyl groups [ δ H 14.10 and 7.04 (each 1H, s)]. The 13 C NMR data ( Table 1 ) with the aid of the HSQC experiment disclosed twenty-three carbon signals attributable to five methyl, three methylene, six methine, and nine non-protonated carbons. A comprehensive analysis of the 1D NMR data of 2a suggested that it was also a phloroglucinol–sesquiterpene adduct.

The planar structure of 2a was established by further analysis of its 2D NMR data. The presence of an acetyl–phloroglucinol moiety ( 2.1 ) was deduced from the characteristic signal of a hydrogen-bonded hydroxyl proton [ δ H 14.10 (1H, s)] and the HMBC correlations from H-4 ( δ H 5.79) to C-3 ( δ C 158.8)/C-5 ( δ C 162.4), H 3 -8 ( δ H 2.68) to C-2 ( δ C 104.9)/C-7 ( δ C 203.6), and 5-OH ( δ H 7.04) to C-4 ( δ C 95.2)/C-5 ( δ C 162.4)/C-6 ( δ C 110.4). Moreover, the remaining fifteen carbons implied the presence of an aristolene unit ( 2.2 ) (
), which was further verified by 1 H– 1 H COSY and HMBC correlations as shown in Fig. 2 . The connection between 2.1 and 2.2 via the C-8 ′ –C-6 bond was accomplished by the key HMBC correlations from H-9’ ( δ H 5.29) to C-6 and from H-8’ ( δ H 3.96) to C-5/C-6. Thus, the planar structure was delineated.

The relative configuration of 2a was determined by interpretation of the NOESY spectrum ( Fig. 4 ), in which the correlations between H-6’ ( δ H 0.72) and H 3 -14’ ( δ H 1.21)/H 3 -15’ ( δ H 0.99), and between H 3 -12’ ( δ H 1.19) and H-6’/H-7’ ( δ H 0.70) indicated that H-6’/H-7’/H 3 -14’/H 3 -15 ′ were occupied on the same side and designated as α -orientation. Thus, the correlation between H-8’ ( δ H 3.96) and H 3 -13’ ( δ H 1.08) indicated that H-8 ′ and H 3 -13 ′ were cofacial and β -oriented. The relative configuration of 2a was determined accordingly. Finally, the tendency of the calculated ECD spectrum of (4 ′ S , 5 ′ S , 6 ′ R , 7 ′ S , 8 ′ R )– 2a agreed with the experimental one, allowing the assignment of the absolute configuration to be 4 ′ S , 5 ′ S , 6 ′ R , 7 ′ S , 8 ′ R .

The molecular formula of dryatraol C ( 3 ) was assigned as C 24 H 32 O 4 by HRESIMS at m/z 385.2370 [M + H] + (calculated for C 24 H 33 O 4 , 385.2373), containing a CH 2 unit more than that of compound 2 . The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of 3 also displayed two similar sets of signals in a 5:2 ratio (in CDCl 3 ), suggesting the presence of two isomers ( 3a and 3b ) similar to those of 2 . The only difference was that the acetyl group ( δ C 203.6, 32.9) in 2a was replaced by a propionyl group ( δ C 206.7, 37.4, 8.9) in 3a , which was confirmed by 1 H– 1 H COSY cross-peaks of H 2 -8 ( δ H 3.10) and H 3 -9 ( δ H 1.18), and the HMBC correlation from H 2 -8 to C-7 ( δ C 206.7). Owing to the structural similarities and identical experimental ECD spectra between 3 and 2 , the absolute configuration of (4 ′ S , 5 ′ S , 6 ′ R , 7 ′ S , 8 ′ R )- 3 was assigned.

Dryatraol D ( 4 ) possessed a molecular formula of C 21 H 26 O 6 with nine degrees of unsaturation, as established by the HRESIMS ion peak at m/z 375.1801 [M + H] + (calculated for C 21 H 27 O 6 , 375.1802). Careful analysis of the 1D NMR data of 4 indicated the presence of an identical phloroglucinol unit ( 4.1 ) as 1 , and the remaining ten signals were attributed to a similar unit ( 4.2 ) of 5-[( E )-hexylidene]-5 H- furan-2-one (
). The main difference was that a pair of double bond carbons in 5-[( E )-hexylidene]-5 H -furan-2-one was replaced by an oxygenated non-pronated carbon ( δ C 117.7) and a methine carbon ( δ C 48.0). A comprehensive interpretation of the 2D NMR data further established the construction of 4 . Two spin systems from H-3’’ ( δ H 6.40) to H-4’’ ( δ H 7.45) and from H-3’ ( δ H 3.57) to H-8’ ( δ H 0.87), together with the HMBC correlations from H-3’’/H-4 ′′ to C-2’’ ( δ C 169.0)/C-2’ ( δ C 117.7), from H-3 ′ to C-2’/C-4’’ ( δ C 149.3) supported the construction of fraction 4.2 . The key HMBC correlations between H-3 ′ and C-3 ( δ C 157.4)/C-4 ( δ C 106.2) indicated that fragment 4.1 and fragment 4.2 were connected via C-4 and C-3’. Similarly, an oxygen bridge between C-2 ′ and C-5 to form a furan ring was identified by the downfield chemical shifts of C-5 ( δ C 156.2) and C-2’ ( δ C 117.7), as well as the molecular formular information.

The relative configuration of 4 was determined using the NOESY spectrum and coupling constants data. The correlation between H-4’’ ( δ H 7.45) and H 2 -4’ ( δ H 1.70) indicated that H 2 -4 ′ and H-4 ′′ were located on the same side. The coupling constant ( J ′′ 3,4’’ = 5.6 Hz) indicated the Z -geometry of the C-3’’/C-4 ′′ olefin. Finally, the absolute configuration was established as 2 ′ S , 3 ′ R by comparing the calculated and experimental ECD spectra.

Dryatraol E ( 5 ) was obtained as colorless crystals (MeOH). The HRESIMS data revealed a pseudo -molecular ion peak [M + H] + at m/ z 431.2791, which was consistent with the molecular formula of C 26 H 38 O 5 (calculated for C 26 H 39 O 5 , 431.2792). Detailed analysis of the 1D NMR data of 5 indicated a similar phloroglucinol moiety ( 5.1 ) as that ( 2.1 ) of 2 and the same sesquiterpenoid moiety ( 5.2 ) as that of hyperjaponol G (
). The difference between 5.1 and 2.1 was that the acetyl ( δ C 203.6, 32.9) in 2.1 was replaced by a butyryl ( δ C 207.5, 46.8, 19.6, 14.4). This deduction was further confirmed by the spin system from H 2 -9 ( δ H 3.02) to H 3 -11 ( δ H 0.97) displayed in the 1 H– 1 H COSY spectrum, together with the HMBC correlation from H 2 -9 to C-8 ( δ C 207.5). Then, 5.1 was incorporated into 5.2 to form a pyran ring, which was supported by the HMBC correlations from H 2 -7 to C-1 ( δ C 164.3)/C-5 ( δ C 162.0)/C-6 ( δ C 101.9)/C-1 ′ ( δ C 83.4) and the 1 H– 1 H COSY cross-peaks of H 2 -7 and H-2 ′ . Thus, the planar structure of 5 with a 6/6/10 ring system was established.

However, the relative configuration of 5 could not be completely determined by NMR spectroscopy. Fortunately, a single crystal of 5 was successfully obtained, and X-ray crystallography analysis with Cu Kα radiation resulted in a Flack parameter of 0.00 (16) allowing an explicit assignment of the absolute conformation as 1 ′ R , 2 ′ S , 5 ′ S , 8 ′ R ( Fig. 3 ; CCDC: 1,903,935). Consequently, the structure of 5 was established, and named as dryatraol E.

Dryatraol F ( 6 ) was obtained as a light yellow gum. The molecular formula was deduced as C 27 H 40 O 5 from the protonated molecular ion peak at m/z 445.2939 [M + H] + (calcd for C 27 H 41 O 5 , 445.2949). Its 1 H NMR spectrum (Figure S62, Supplementary data) showed two signals at δ H 18.98 and δ H 18.32 in a very low field with a ratio of approximately 5:1, suggesting the presence of two isomers ( 6a and 6b ). Further analysis of the 1D NMR data suggested the acetylfilicinic acid moiety ( 6.1 ) identical to that of dryocrassoid B (
), which led to keto-enol tautomerism, as previously reported. In the HMBC spectrum, the major signal for the hydrogen-bonded hydroxyl proton ( δ H 18.98) was observed to be correlated with C-1 ( δ C 188.0)/C-2 ( δ C 105.4)/C-6 ( δ C 101.6)/C-8 ( δ C 204.5) of 6a . While, the minor signal δ H 18.32 showed correlations with C-2 ( δ C 108.6)/C-3 ( δ C 197.4)/C-8 ( δ C 208.5) of 6b . These differences supported that 6a and 6b were a pair of keto-enol tautomers as depicted in Fig. 1 . Additionally, a detailed comparison of the 1D NMR data between 6 and 5 revealed the presence of the same germacrene-type sesquiterpene moiety ( 6.2 ). With the aid of the 1 H– 1 H COSY, HSQC, and HMBC spectra ( Fig. 2 ), the 1 H and 13 C NMR data were assigned, as shown in Table 2 . The linkage between 6.1 and 6.2 via a pyran ring similar to that of 5 was supported by the 1 H– 1 H COSY cross-peaks of H 2 -7 ( δ H 2.79, 1.73) and H-2 ′ ( δ H 1.52), HMBC correlations from H 2 -7 to C-5 ( δ C 173.2)/C-6 ( δ C 101.6)/C-1 ′ ( δ C 84.9), and the molecular formula information. Finally, the configuration of 6 was determined by comparing the experimental and calculated ECD spectra ( Fig. 5 ). Thus, the structure of 6 was constructed as depicted.

The molecular formulas of dryatraol G ( 7 ) and dryatraol H ( 8 ) were assigned as C 26 H 38 O 5 and C 28 H 42 O 5 by the ion peaks at m/z 431.2784 [M + H] + (calcd for C 26 H 39 O 5 , 431.2792) and m/z 459.3096 [M + H] + (calcd for C 28 H 43 O 5 , 459.3105) in their HRESIMS spectra, respectively. They respectively showed fourteen ( CH 2 ) mass units less and more than that of 6 . Detailed and careful analysis of the NMR data showed high similarity to those of 6 indicated that compounds 7 and 8 were also mixtures of two isomers with the same ratio as that of 6 . The only difference was that the propionyl group ( δ C 204.5, 33.5, 9.1) in 6 was replaced by an acetyl group ( δ C 200.4, 28.1) in 7 and a butyryl group ( δ C 203.3, 41.6, 18.6, 14.0) in 8 , respectively. These conclusions were respectively confirmed by the HMBC correlations from H 3 -9 ( δ H 2.58, s) to C-8 ( δ C 200.4) in 7 , and from H 2 -9 ( δ H 2.97) to C-8 ( δ C 203.3) in 8 , and the 1 H– 1 H COSY spin system of H 2 -9 H
3 -11 in
8 ( Fig. 2 ). Thus, the 2D structures of 7 and 8 were elucidated, and the configurations were determined to be the same as that of 6 , which was further confirmed by comparison with the experimental ECD spectra ( Fig. 5 ).

Dryatraol I ( 9 ) possessed the same molecular formula of C 28 H 42 O 5 as 8 based on the HRESIMS ion peak m/z 459.3100 [M + H] + (calcd for C 28 H 43 O 5 , 459.3105) and 13 C NMR data. Detailed analysis of the 1D NMR of 9 indicated that it was an analogue of hyperjaponol G except that the iso -butyryl group ( δ C 201.6, 35.9, 20.5, 19.7) in hyperjaponol G was replaced by a butyryl group ( δ C 197.0, 42.1, 20.4, 14.6) in 9 . This was verified by the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of H 2 -9 ( δ H 3.06) to H 3 -11 ( δ H 1.02) and the HMBC correlations between H 2 -9 ( δ H 3.06)/H 2 -10 ( δ H 1.75) and C-8 ( δ C 197.0). Therefore, the planar structure of 9 was identified. Then, the relative and absolute configurations were determined by comparison of the 1D NMR data, NOESY correlations, and experimental ECD spectrum with those of 6–8 and hyperjaponol G, respectively.

In addition to these undescribed compounds, three known acylphloroglucinols were identified as norflavaspidic acid AA, norflavaspidic acid AP, and norflavaspidic acid AB by comparing the spectroscopic and physical data with the respective literature values (
).

sec.title: 2.2. Pharmacological activity
sec.p: The isolates were evaluated for their antiviral activities in vitro against RSV, HSV-1, and H1N1 using a cytopathic effect (CPE) reduction assay. As shown in Table 3 , most of the tested compounds displayed different degrees of antiviral activity against HSV-1, with IC 50 values ranging from 2.6 to 47.5 μM, while fewer compounds showed activity against RSV and H1N1 (A/PR/8/34). Compounds 2 and 3 displayed comparable antiviral effects against H1N1 (A/PR/8/34) to the positive control. Compounds 6–8 showed substantial inhibitory effects against HSV-1, with IC 50 values ranging from 2.6 to 6.3 μM. Furthermore, a time-of-addition assay indicated that the most remarkable compound 7 exerted its anti-HSV-1 activity by inhibiting the late [L]-phase among the virus replication phases ( Fig. 6 ). However, the detailed mechanism still requires further investigation.

sec.title: 3. Conclusion
sec.p:
In the present study, nine undescribed phloroglucinol derivatives and three known dimeric acylphloroglucinols were obtained from the rhizome of
D. atrata
. Their structures were determined using comprehensive spectroscopic data, X-ray diffraction, and quantum chemical ECD calculations. The antiviral activity assays revealed that some of the isolates displayed considerable antiviral effects against RSV, HSV-1, and H1N1. In summary, these findings enrich the record of chemical diversity of the phloroglucinol derivatives from
Dryopteris
. In addition, some these active compounds may be useful for developing medicinal antiviral agents.

sec.title: 4.1. General experimental procedures
sec.p: Optical rotations were recorded on a JASCO P–1020 polarimeter. HRESIMS data were determined on an Agilent 6210 LC/MSD TOF mass spectrometer. A JASCO V–550 UV/vis spectrophotometer was used for scanning UV spectra. 1D and 2D NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker AV–400 ( 1 H: 400 MHz, 13 C: 100 MHz), Bruker AV–500 ( 1 H: 500 MHz, 13 C: 125 MHz), and Bruker AV–600 ( 1 H: 600 MHz, 13 C: 150 MHz) spectrometers with TMS as an internal standard. Analytical HPLC (high–performance liquid chromatography) was performed through a Shimadzu LC system equipped with an LC–20AD pump and an SPDM-20 A PDA detector, as well as a Cosmosil C 18 analytical column (5 μm, 4.6 × 250 mm ). Preparative HPLC was carried out on a Varian Prostar system equipped with a preparative Cosmosil C 18 column (5 μm, 20 × 250 mm ). Open column chromatography (CC) was performed using silica gel (200–300, mesh), ODS (50 μm, 120 Å; YMC) and Sephadex LH–20 (25–100 μm). All reagents used in CC and HPLC were analytical grade and chromatographic grade, respectively.
4.2. Plant materials

The rhizomes of
Dryopteris atrata (Wall. Ex Kunze) Ching (Dryopteridaceae)
were collected in Yunnan Province of China (
21.10 ◦ N
,
100.80 ◦ E
) in
September of 2019
. The plant was authenticated by Prof. Guangxiong Zhou (College of Pharmacy, Jinan University). A voucher specimen (No. 2019092601 ) was deposited in the Institute of Traditional Chinese Medicine & Natural Products , Jinan University, Guangzhou, China
.
4.3. Extraction and isolation

The dried and powered rhizomes of
D. atrata
(8.0 kg) were extracted four times with 95% ethanol at room temperature (4 × 60.0 L). After filtration, the solvent was removed under reduced pressure using a rotary evaporator to give a crude extract ( 1.1 kg ), which was suspended in water (1.0 L) and then partitioned with petroleum ether (PE) (3 × 3.0 L). After removal of solvent, the entire PE extract ( 250.7 g ) was subjected to a silica gel CC eluted with PE/ethyl acetate (EA) in a gradient (100:0 to 0:100, v/v) to give seven fractions (Fr. A to Fr. G). Fr. C ( 53.2 g ) was further purified by Sephadex LH-20 (chloroform (CHCl 3 )/methanol (MeOH), 1:1, v/v) to obtain five subfractions (Fr. C1 to Fr. C5). Fr. C3 ( 20.7 g ) was loaded on an ODS CC with a step gradient solvent of MeOH/ water (H 2 O) (30:70 to 100:0, v/v) to afford ten subfractions (Fr. C3a to Fr. C3j). Compounds 1 ( 4.2 mg , t R 34.0 min) and 4 (6.0 mg, t R 25.0 min) were isolated from Fr. C3d ( 0.7 g ) by preparative HPLC [MeOH/H 2 O (0.1% formic acid (HCOOH)), 85:15, v/v]. Compounds 2 ( 10.6 mg , t R 33.0 min), 3 ( 6.4 mg , t R 36.0 min), and 9 (3.0 mg, t R 32.0 min) were obtained from Fr. C3e ( 1.2 g ) using preparative HPLC [MeOH/H 2 O (0.1% HCOOH), 85:15, v/v]. Fr. C3f ( 0.7 g ) was isolated by semipreparative HPLC [MeOH/H 2 O (0.1% HCOOH), 85:15, v/v] to obtain 5 ( 4.2 mg , t R 27.0 min) and 7 ( 3.6 mg , t R 33.0 min). Compounds 6 (5.0 mg, t R 23.0 min) and 8 ( 6.3 mg , t R 27.0 min) were acquired from Fr. C3i ( 0.8 g ) by preparative HPLC [MeOH/H 2 O (0.1% HCOOH), 90:10, v/v]. Fr. A (27.0 g) was subjected to a silica gel CC eluted with a gradient mixture of PE/EA (100:0 to 0:100, v/v), and then divided into three parts (Fr. A1 to Fr. A3). Fr. A2 (9.0 g) was chromatographed on an ODS CC using MeOH/ H 2 O (40:60 to 100:0, v/v) as eluent to afford seven parts (Fr. A2a to Fr. A 2g ). Compounds 10 ( 10.2 mg , t R 24.0 min), 11 ( 12.6 mg , t R 30.0 min), and 12 ( 15.5 mg , t R 36.0 min) were obtained from Fr. A2d (1.0 g) by preparative HPLC [MeOH/H 2 O (0.1% trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)), 90:10, v/v].

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Overlapped signals are reported without designating multiplicity.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: a Measured in CDCl.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 3 b Measured in C D N.

sec.title: 4.4. Spectroscopic data of compounds
sec.p: Dryatraol A (1) : yellow oil; [ α ]25 D +43 ( c 0.1, MeOH); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δε) 219 (+9.0), 291 (+34.5); UV–vis (MeOH) λ max 226, 291 nm ; IR (KBr) ν max 3412, 2924, 2860, 1687, 1617, 1451, 1370, 1196, 1127, 1031, 861, 805 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 427.2476 [M + H] + (calculated for C 26 H 35 O 5 , 427.2479).

Dryatraol B (2) : yellow oil; [ α ]25 D 51 ( c 0.1, MeOH); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δε) 212 (43.8); UV–vis (MeOH) λ max 226, 291 nm ; IR (KBr) ν max 3477, 3366, 2929, 2865, 1616, 1441, 1367, 1261, 1169, 1070, 879, 823 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 371.2214 [M + H] + (calculated for C 23 H 31 O 4 , 371.2217).

Dryatraol C (3) : yellow oil; [ α ]25 D 47 ( c 0.1, MeOH); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δε) 212 (53.2); UV–vis (MeOH) λ max 229, 290 nm ; IR (KBr) ν max 3474, 3356, 2930, 2858, 1623, 1442, 1365, 1278, 1169, 1074, 971, 881, 823 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 385.2370 [M + H] + (calculated for C 24 H 33 O 4 , 385.2373).

Dryatraol D (4) : orange oil; [ α ]25 D +23 ( c 0.6, MeOH); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δε) 207 (+28.3), 241 (13.3), 365 (+3.5); UV–vis (MeOH) λ max 226, 291 nm ; IR (KBr) ν max 3426, 2948, 2877, 1677, 1580, 1429, 1252, 1166, 1094, 1052, 957, 893 cm 1 . 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 375.1801 [M + H] + (calculated for C 21 H 27 O 6 , 375.1802).

Dryatraol E (5) : colorless needles; [ α ]25 D +15 ( c 0.5, CH 3 CN); UV–vis ( CH 3 CN) λ max 195, 291 nm ; IR (KBr) ν max : 3395, 2962, 2940, 1623, 1592, 1432, 1380, 1173, 1141, 1065, 920, 879, 818 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 431.2791 [M + H] + (calculate for C 26 H 39 O 5 , 431.2792).

Dryatraol F ( 6 ): violet gum; [ α ]25 D +37 ( c 0.2, MeOH); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δε) 228 (+25.3); UV–vis (MeOH) λ max 225, 242, 274, 327 nm ; IR (KBr) ν max 3513, 3460, 2971, 2933, 2877, 1659, 1617, 1527, 1458, 1379, 1194, 1062, 943, 881 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 445.2939 [M + H] + (calculate for C 27 H 41 O 5 , 445.2949).

Dryatraol G (7) : yellow gum; [ α ]25 D +28 ( c 1.0, CH 3 CN); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δε) 228 (+21.3); UV–vis ( CH 3 CN) λ max : 194, 223, 245, 273, 330 nm ; IR (KBr) ν max : 3389, 2962, 2939, 1620, 1592, 1429, 1383, 1170, 1147, 1065, 990, 929, 813 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 431.2784 [M + H] + (calculate for C 26 H 39 O 5 , 431.2792).

Dryatraol H (8) : violet gum; [ α ]25 D +25 ( c 0.2, MeOH); ECD (MeOH) λ max (Δε) 228 (+19.3); UV–vis (MeOH) λ max 225, 241, 273, 326 nm ; IR (KBr) ν max 3460, 2967, 2933, 2879, 1659, 1619, 1532, 1464, 1378, 1267, 1193, 1145, 1059, 993, 838 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 459.3096 [M + H] + (calculate for C 28 H 43 O 5 , 459.3105).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: a IC is the concentration of compound that reduced 50% CPE as compared with control cells infected with virus and data were expressed as mean (n = 3).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 50 b CC is the concentration of compound with half maximal inhibition on the growth and survival of host cells.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 50 c Selectivity index (SI) = CC /IC.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 50 50 d The positive controls.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: e Not active at the tested concentration.

sec.title: 4.5. X-ray crystallographic analysis
sec.p:
Crystallographic data of dryatraol E. Colorless needles, C 26 H 38 O 5 ( M = 430.56 g /mol), orthorhombic, space group P212121 (no. 19), a = 9.1424 (1) Å, b = 14.1834 (2) Å, c = 18.0517 (2) Å, V = 2340.77 (5) Å 3 , Z = 4, μ (Cu Kα) = 0.663 mm 1 , D calc = 1.2217 g /cm 3 , 19,672 reflections measured (7.92 ◦ ≤ 2θ ≤ 148.36 ◦ ), 4608 unique ( R int = 0.0498, R sigma = 0.0381) which were used in all calculations. The final
R 1
was 0.0455 (4320) and wR 2 was 0.1193 (4608), Flack parameter: 0.00 (16). Crystallographic data for the structure has been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center as CCDC 1903935.

sec.title: 4.6. ECD calculations
sec.p:
Conformational analysis of compounds 1 , 2a , 4 and 6a were carried out via random searching in SYBYL 8.1 program by using the MMFF94S force field with an energy cutoff of 10.0 kcal mol 1 . Subsequently, the conformers were further optimized using DFT at the B3LYP/6-31 + G(d) level by using Gaussian09 software (Frisch et al., 2009). The ECD spectra were computed by DFT calculations at the same level of theory with UV correction, and produced by SpecDis 1.6 software (
).

sec.title: 4.7. In vitro anti-viral assay
sec.p: The isolated compounds were evaluated for their antiviral activities in vitro against RSV, HSV-1 and H1N1 by using the CPE reduction assay. The details, including the time-of-addition assay of dryatraol G against HSV-1, were described in Supplementary data.
Declaration of competing interest
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
Data availability
Data will be made available on request.
Acknowledgement

sec.title: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sec.p: Supplementary data related to this article can be found at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2023.113585.
